object_colour:multicoloured
physical_appearance:This is a multicoloured map of Southeast Asia
 created by Nicolas Visscher I and published by Pieter Schenk Jr. There are many words at the top of the map
 highlighting the names of places in Southeast Asia where the Dutch East India Company (VOC) extended their control over trade activities. The bottom of the map has lines of text that represent the title and scale of the map.
subject_terms_1:coastlines cartography (discipline)  trade (general function) cartouches (ornament)
subject_terms_2:Pictorial maps Coasts Cartography Nederlandsche Oost-Indische Compagnie East Indies Spice trade India Australia Southeast Asia Cartouches
 Ornamental (Decorative arts)
subject_terms_4:Southeast Asia (general region) India (nation)  Australia (nation) East Indies (general region)
sgcool_label_text:This map of Southeast Asia by Nicolas Visscher was printed in the early 18th century by Pieter Schenk. It depicts the sphere of influence of the Dutch East India Company
 spanning from India to the northern coastline of Australia. The focus
 however
 is that of the East Indies around which the spice trade was centred.

The bottom of the map has lines of text that represent the title and scale of the map.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This map of Southeast Asia by Nicolas Visscher was printed in the early 18th century by Pieter Schenk. It depicts the sphere of influence of the Dutch East India Company, spanning from India to the northern coastline of Australia. The focus, however, is that of the East Indies around which the spice trade was centred.
